Award.AbstractNarration: This research program consists of three lines of investigation, each <br/>connected to multivariate analogues of generalized hypergeometric <br/>functions. The first concerns a family of biorthogonal abelian <br/>functions associated to elliptic curves that generalize multivariate <br/>orthogonal polynomials due to Macdonald and Koornwinder. The second <br/>aspect involves certain multivariate analogues of quadratic <br/>transformations of hypergeometric functions, which generalize identities <br/>from the theory of symmetric spaces; related to this is the study of <br/>natural deformations of permutation actions of Coxeter groups to <br/>representations of the associated Hecke algebras, some of which have led <br/>to proofs of multivariate quadratic transformations. Finally, the <br/>investigator will be studying multivariate elliptic hypergeometric <br/>(contour) integrals, with a view to understanding the functional <br/>equations satisfied by such integrals.<br/><br/>Historically, the study of "special functions" originated in the fact <br/>that quite a few functions of interest in applications turned out to be <br/>members of a single family, the hypergeometric functions. The new <br/>family of functions the investigator is studying is a significant <br/>generalization of this family, combining several existing <br/>generalizations (each with their own applications and connections to <br/>other areas of mathematics) under one roof. In addition to the <br/>potential that new applications may arise, this investigation should <br/>also lead to a greater understanding of the existing families.<br/><br/>
